title: Trust Administrator Guide: Selling Wine and Spirits
metaTitle: Trust Administrator Guide: Selling Wine and Spirits | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: A complete guide for trust administrators on selling wine and spirits assets. Learn how to inventory, verify value, and sell efficiently.
summary: Steps to inventory, document authority, and sell a cellar efficiently and discreetly.

sections.heading: Quick Answer
content: Selling wine and spirits from a trust requires clear authority and distinct steps.
list: Verify you have the specific power to sell personal property or chattels.
Secure the physical assets immediately to prevent theft or spoilage.
Create a preliminary inventory (photos or list).
Get a professional quote before moving any bottles.
Document the transaction for the trust's beneficiaries.

sections.heading: Legal Authority and Documentation
content: Before soliciting offers, ensure you have the correct documentation ready. Buyers will require proof of ownership and your authority to act on behalf of the trust.
list: Certificate of Trust or Abstract of Trust naming you as trustee.
Photo ID matching the trustee name.
A written statement confirming the assets are free of liens.

sections.heading: Inventory and Valuation
content: You do not need to be a wine expert to build a sufficient inventory. Speed and accuracy are key.
Start by photographing the spines of bottles in the rack if legible, or group them by type (e.g., all Bordeaux together).
For spirits, group by brand (e.g., Macallan, Pappy Van Winkle) and take clear photos of the labels and fill levels.

sections.heading: Common Mistakes to Avoid
content: Trust administrators often make avoidable errors that reduce the estate's value.
list: Moving bottles without temperature control, causing heat damage.
Cleaning bottles with water or chemicals, ruining labels.
Selling to the first local shop without getting a specialized market quote.
Assuming all old wine is valuable (condition matters most).

sections.heading: What to Do Next
content: Ready to move forward? Follow this checklist to liquidate the assets.
list: Take wide shots of the cellar and close-ups of key bottles.
Submit photos to us for a preliminary valuation.
Review the offer with legal counsel if required by the trust.

faqs.question: Can I sell wine without a liquor license?
faqs.answer: Yes, in many jurisdictions, an estate or trust can sell wine to a licensed buyer like Proof Cellars without needing its own license. We handle the compliance.

faqs.question: Do I need to appraise every single bottle?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. We provide a portfolio offer for the entire collection, which is often faster and more cost-effective than a per-bottle appraisal.

faqs.question: How quickly can you pay the trust?
faqs.answer: We typically issue payment within 1 business day of inspecting the collection.

faqs.question: What if the trust has multiple beneficiaries?
faqs.answer: We pay the trust entity directly, allowing you to distribute funds according to the trust instrument.

faqs.question: Do you maximize value for the estate?
faqs.answer: Yes, we offer market-based pricing that usually exceeds local liquidation options.
